name: exec_robot_create_thread
description:
Starts a background controller thread for a specific robot. Validates that the robot_id exists in Data/robot_pos.txt (lines formatted as id,x,y,theta). If the ID doesn't exist, returns "Selected ID doesn't exist". If a thread for this robot is already running, returns "Thread already running for robot <id>". On success, returns "Started thread for robot <id>".

The controller reads targets from Targets/path.txt, reads poses from Data/robot_pos.txt, writes wheel commands to Data/command.txt, and logs errors to Data/error.txt. Other robots can be treated as circular obstacles via robot_padding.

Example Usage: "exec_robot_create_thread(robot_id=782)"

robot_id.description: ID of the robot to control (matches the first column in Data/robot_pos.txt). Example: 782.

robot_padding.description: Radius (in pixels) to stamp around OTHER robots as obstacles. Set 0 to ignore other robots. Default: 30.

name: stop_robot_thread
description:
Stops the running controller thread for the given robot_id. Signals the thread's stop_event and waits up to join_timeout seconds for it to exit. Returns "Stopped thread for robot <id>" if it finishes in time, "Stop requested; robot <id> is still stopping" if it hasn't finished yet, or "No running thread for robot <id>" if none is active.

Example Usage: "stop_robot_thread(robot_id=782)"

robot_id.description: ID of the robot whose thread should be stopped.

join_timeout.description: Seconds to wait for the thread to join after signaling stop. Default: 5.0.
